awd_titl_txt: The Covers, Symmetries, and Combinatorics of Manifolds
awd_abstract_narration:
Geometry and topology are concerned with the study of shapes. In Euclidean geometry, we study objects such as circles and rectangles. A circle is highly symmetric; for example, any rotation about the center of the circle preserves the circle. A rectangle, though still symmetric in some ways, has less symmetry than the circle; its two sides may have different lengths. In low-dimensional topology we study more complicated objects or spaces of two, three, and four dimensions. A central aim of this National Science Foundation funded project is to understand these spaces through symmetries. Topological objects arise naturally in other fields, including biology, chemistry, physics, and engineering.  At times, the best way to understand one is via its relationship with another through what is known as a "covering map". A second project is to analyze covering maps. A challenge in studying more intricate three or four dimensional spaces is that one cannot always visualize or draw these even using a computer. It is therefore helpful to break them into building blocks. One of the projects is to do so with objects called hyperbolic 3-manifolds.  In addition to the mathematical research, the PI has demonstrated a strong dedication to outreach, mentoring, and advocating for underrepresented individuals in the STEM disciplines. With the NSF travel funds she will continue to engage in opportunities inside and outside the academia directed at promoting mathematical research and education. 


The focus of this research project is to understand the finite degree covering spaces, the group of symmetries, and the combinatorics of hyperbolic manifolds in low dimensions. The PI plans to tackle the following projects during the funding period: (1) making effective the Virtually Haken Theorem, (2) quantifying separability properties to determine whether or not the fundamental groups of three-manifolds and the mapping class groups of closed surfaces are linear, (3) exploring infinite-type surfaces, their mapping class groups, and the actions of these groups on hyperbolic complexes, and (4) giving a combinatorial characterization for hyperbolic three-manifolds. Though the research project primarily focuses on questions in topology, geometry, and geometric group theory, the topics explored by the PI have deep connections to combinatorics, representation theory, dynamics, and topological quantum field theory (TQFT) as well.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intelletual Merit: 

During the 3-year time period of this grant, the PI completed 5 papers, 3 of which have already been published. One additional paper that was completed before the start date of the grant was also published. Two of the papers, “Effective virtual and residual properties of some arithmetic hyperbolic 3-manifolds” (with DeBlois and Miller) and “Covers of surfaces, Kleinian groups, and the curve complex” (with Aougab and Taylor) work towards the PI’s long-term goal of quantifying the virtual Haken conjecture. Two of the other papers “Isometry groups of infinite-genus hyperbolic surfaces” (with Aougab and Vlamis) and “Stable commutator length on big mapping class groups” (with Field and Rasmussen) are big steps forward in the PI’s research program regarding infinite-type surfaces. The first of these two has already proven to be quite influential in shaping some of the future research directions regarding infinite-type surface and their groups of symmetries. The fifth paper “Free products from spinning and rotating families” (with Bestvina, Dickmann, Domat, Kwak, and Stark) was born out of a learning seminar on projection complexes at the University of Utah. 

 

Broader Impacts: 

During the 3 years of the grant period, the PI moved from a postdoctoral position at UCSB to a tenure-track position at the University of Utah. As the only woman faculty member in pure math in her department and the only woman of color across both pure and applied math faculty member in her department, she understands acutely the importance of advocating for and supporting women and people of color in both her local and global communities. 

 

The PI is dedicated to equity, diversity, and inclusion (EDI) efforts at the departmental, college, and university levels. Along with a colleague, the PI recently formed and became an inaugural member of the EDI Committee in her department. Through her role on this committee last year, the PI was a member of the graduate admissions committee in her department and was responsible for upholding the department's EDI values throughout the admissions process. At the university level, the PI has participated in workshops regarding inclusive mentoring and teaching diversity designated courses (e.g. mathematics courses with integrated components related to ethics). She also recently served on a search committee for the new Assistant Vice President of Faculty Diversity and Equity at the University of Utah.

 

Locally, the PI organizes the Max Dehn Seminar (topology and dynamics seminar), organized the UCSB Topology Seminar, and co-organized an RTG Workshop on Riemann Surfaces for graduate students in February of 2020. She is also organized a year-long Virtual Learning Seminar on infinite-type surfaces with 15 participants from the University of Utah, including undergrads, grad students, postdocs, and faculty. More broadly, the PI co-organized an AIM workshop on infinite-type surfaces in April of 2019. This workshop brought together 30 individuals studying infinite-type surfaces from different perspectives for the first time. It was incredibly fruitful, resulting in a list of 50 questions and clearly outlining some of the biggest open problems in the area.

 

The PI is also one of four co-PIs on the University of Utah RTG Grant in Algebra, Geometry, and Topology. Aside from the usual duties of managing RTG funding, she is one of two faculty members in charge of the joint AWM-RTG Speaker Series. This series brings one highly accomplished woman mathematics professor to the University of Utah each semester to give a research talk, give a ``pathway in mathematics" talk, and to meet with the students of the AWM chapter through an informal tea. In terms of outreach and education work, the PI has given workshops at ``Science Day at the U" (for local high school students), at ``Defining Your Path" (a middle school outreach event), and for the ACCESS Program (for incoming undergraduate women at the University of Utah interested in STEM).
